instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used to solve the adulteration problem of brown rice flour in the commodity market?
Output: In the detection method proposed in this research, laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (TR-LIBS) was used.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were employed in the analysis of the adulteration in brown rice flour?
Output: Time-resolved Laser-Induced Breakdown Spectroscopy (TR-LIBS) was employed in the analysis of the adulteration in brown rice flour.

instruction: To solve the adulteration problem of brown rice flour in the commodity market, What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the detection method and how far can this metric go?
Output: The metric used to solve the adulteration problem of brown rice flour in the commodity market was classification accuracy. The classification accuracy of the traditional machine learning models (LDA, NB, and SVM) based on TR-LIBS had a significant improvement of 3-11% compared to traditional LIBS. Additionally, the deep learning classification model based on TR-LIBS achieved similar results with an accuracy increase of more than 8%.

instruction: What machine learning models were used to analyze the adulteration in brown rice flour in this research?
Output: The machine learning models used to analyze the adulteration in brown rice flour in this research were linear discriminant analysis (LDA), naive Bayes (NB), and support vector machine (SVM).

instruction: How does the performance of the proposed TR-LIBS detection method compare to traditional methods in identifying brown rice flour adulteration?
Output:
The performance of the proposed TR-LIBS detection method is significantly better than traditional methods in identifying brown rice flour adulteration. For qualitative analysis, the machine learning models based on TR-LIBS (LDA, NB, and SVM) have classification accuracy that is 3-11% higher than those based on traditional LIBS. The deep learning classification model based on TR-LIBS also achieves similar results with an accuracy increase of more than 8%. 

For quantitative analysis, the quantitative model based on TR-LIBS reduces the limit of detection (LOD) of five adulterants from about 8-51% to 4-19%, effectively improving the quantitative detection performance. 

Additionally, t-SNE visualization demonstrates that there are more obvious boundaries between different types of samples based on TR-LIBS, further highlighting the superior performance of this method in identifying brown rice flour adulteration.
